Dialogue.content: Hi, I'm Ethan Williams. It's nice to meet you.
Hi Ethan! It's great to meet you too. How are you feeling today?
I'm feeling a bit overwhelmed with the start of the semester. There's a lot going on in my Environmental Science classes.
I understand. Starting a new semester can be quite challenging, especially with demanding coursework. What's been the most overwhelming part for you?
I just finished a really tough field study project and got feedback that felt more critical than helpful. It made me question my abilities.
That sounds really tough. Receiving criticism, especially when we're already feeling pressure, can be discouraging. How did that feedback affect you personally?
It left me anxious and feeling like I'm not good enough, especially since my dad is a park ranger and has high expectations.
It's natural to feel that way, especially with family expectations in mind. Have you had a chance to talk to anyone about how you're feeling?
Not yet. I don't want to seem weak or like I can't handle my studies.
It's important to remember that everyone has struggles. Sharing your feelings can actually open doors for support. Would you consider talking to someone in your family or your friends?
I think I could talk to my sister Mia. She might understand what I'm going through.
Hi again, I talked to Mia about my feelings.
That's great to hear, Ethan! How did that conversation go?
It helped a little, but I still find it hard to share my ideas in group projects. I feel overshadowed by my classmates.
It's understandable to feel that way in a talkative group. What do you think might help you speak up in those situations?
I guess I could set a goal to contribute at least once in our next meeting, but I worry I may not articulate myself well.
Setting that goal sounds like a constructive step forward. Remember, the value of your contributions isn't measured just by how eloquently you speak. Would practicing your ideas beforehand help?
Yes, I think that could boost my confidence.
That's a great plan! Also, remind yourself that everyone learns and grows at their own pace. You'll find your voice.
Thanks for the encouragement. I'll attempt to implement this strategy.
Hi! I'm back, but I'm feeling increasingly anxious.
Hi Ethan! I'm glad you came back. What's been happening this week?
I attended a family gathering, and my dad was showcasing his photography. I felt really inadequate afterward.
I'm sorry to hear that. It can be difficult to be around family when you feel that way. How did it impact your feelings about your own pursuits in environmental science?
It made me worry that I'm not living up to the family's expectations or my own aspirations. I keep thinking I'm not cut out for this.
It's perfectly normal to feel that way, especially in a creative and challenging field. Have you taken any moments to reflect on your own growth and passion for environmental science?
Not really. I've been pretty fixated on comparing myself to them.
It might help to reflect on what you enjoy about your studies and to remind yourself of your accomplishments. You've worked hard to get where you are.
Hi, I'm back! I took some time to think about my motivations and reasons for pursuing environmental science.
Hi Ethan! That's wonderful to hear! How did that reflection go?
It really helped me remember why I chose this path in the first place. I'm passionate about conservation and protecting nature.
That's fantastic! Holding onto that passion can help guide you during tough times. How are you feeling now about engaging in your program?
I feel a bit more optimistic, but I still struggle with participating in group discussions.
It's great to hear that positivity! For group discussions, perhaps you can share your passion, making it relatable for you. What's one small way you could engage in class next time?
I think I could start small by sharing my thoughts on a recent environmental issue we learned about in class.
